Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research--Microscopic Islands: Modeling the Theory of Island Biogeography for Aquatic Pathogens Colonizing Marine Aggregates
Award.AbstractNarration:
The theory of island biogeography, seminal to modern ecological thinking, has been invoked hundreds of times to explain colonization sequences and species richness on "islands" of many sizes and in many locations. These applications have overwhelmingly focused on macro-organisms (among them lizards, birds, and beetles) and practically ignored microorganisms.

In this project investigators at four U.S. research universities -- Old Dominion University, University of Georgia, University of Minnesota at Duluth, and University of Connecticut -- will apply the theory more provocatively: to infectious disease ecology. They argue that organic-rich marine and freshwater aggregates (synonyms include: marine snow, freshwater snow, organic detritus, and bioflocs) serve as "microscopic islands" for bacteria in aquatic environments. The theory?s relevance in this context will be tested through development of analytical models parameterized by empirical studies in both field and laboratory. Using a three-step approach, the research team (microbial ecologists, infectious-disease modeler, shellfish biologist/ physiologist) together will: (1) Design and experimentally test an analytical model of island biogeography applied to individual aggregates ("islands") to predict bacterial species richness as a function of aggregate size and distance from a point source of pathogens (Species richness of marine aggregates); (2) Use the outputs from the species-richness model to construct and experimentally analyze a second mathematical model that considers the persistence of pathogenic species within the microbial communities of aggregates. The effects, if any, of species richness on persistence will also be determined (Pathogen persistence in marine aggregates); and (3) Apply information from the species-richness model and the pathogen-persistence model to evaluate links between marine aggregates and public health with an agent-based simulation model. The long-term goal of the principal investigators is to bring a community-level approach to studies of infectious diseases in aquatic environments.

The broader impacts of this proposed research are many. Graduate students at all four participating universities will be trained, and two post-doctoral researchers will be supported and mentored. In addition, ambitious outreach efforts will develop innovative, inquiry-based teaching materials for students from grades K-12. These materials advocate basic ecological principles of infectious diseases, helping to fill a void in resources available for this topic. Between them, these institutions host more than 30,000 school children and educators annually, providing the NSF Ecology of Infectious Diseases program an immense and diverse audience for disseminating this project's interactive demonstrations and activities and in so doing, enhance the public understanding of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative interdisciplinary project examined how clumps of organic material act as island-like habitats for aquatic microbes. Previous work had shown that organic aggregates can contain disease-causing bacteria such as Vibrio sp. and Escherichia coli, suggesting that they may play a role in the dynamics of these pathogens and the risk of exposure of humans and animals. Inspired by the ecological theory of island biogeography, first developed by E.O. Wilson and Robert MacArthur in the 1960s, objectives of the study were to understand how aggregate size and concentration of bacteria in the water affects the community of bacteria present on the aggregate, how rapidly species colonize and die out on aggregates, and how these dynamics influence pathogen accumulation in organisms feeding on the bacteria and aggregates in the water. The work involved development of two linked computer models, one of bacterial dynamics on aggregates and one representing a population of oysters in water containing aggregates and bacteria. These models were complemented with empirical work by collaborators to measure presence of potentially pathogenic bacteria on marine aggregates (Figure 1, from Lyons et al 2010).

Empirical results confirmed that aggregates are acting as islands of favorable habitat, resulting in high densities of heterotrophic bacteria, some of which are pathogenic. The community behaves as predicted by ecological theory with a dynamic equilibrium between the colonization and extinction of species. To investigate this pattern further, we extended a mechanistic model of colonization and extinction that considers the physics of aggregates, the concentration of bacteria in the water, bacterial growth and consumption by flagellate and ciliate consumers. The model was simulated (Figure 2) to allow for accurate estimates of extinction rates and the number of bacteria on aggregates of different sizes. Simulation outcomes show the relationship between pathogen cell density in the water and the size of aggregates to be nonlinear, resulting in a substantial enrichment of bacteria when large aggregates are in water with high concentrations of bacteria in the surrounding water. This model makes the first predictions about dynamics of individual bacterial species on aggregates, which may lead to future studies that would investigate microscopic causes for observed patterns in abundance on aggregates of species such as V. vulnificus or V. parahaemolyticus. Using results of this model as a baseline, we then developed an individual-based model of oyster feeding behavior to investigate how microscopic fluctuations on aggregates might “scale up” to affects human health. Aggregates have been implicated as potential vectors that increase uptake of pathogenic bacteria into shellfish such as oysters, thereby increasing human health risk. Based on the models, aggregates greatly increase the accumulation of pathogen when pathogen density is high in the water, but do not act as effective transporters at lower bacterial densities (Figure 3). The model also suggests that measuring the tendency of particular pathogen species to either easily detach or stick strongly to aggregates is a key future step to understanding how aggregates will influence pathogen uptake.

The project contributed to training of a postdoctoral fellow and graduate student at the University of Georgia. It enabled a professor and three undergraduate students at Bethel College to participate in research. The undergraduates developed skills in mathematical analysis and co-authored a peer-reviewed journal article.
